MC: Basic life support (BLS) is defined as:

column3: a) invasive emergency medical interventions such as intravenous therapy, manual defibrillation, and advanced airway management.
b) any form of emergency medical treatment that is performed by advanced EMTs, paramedics, physicians, and emergency nurses.
c) basic lifesaving treatment that is performed by bystanders while EMS providers are en route to the scene of an emergency.
d) noninvasive emergency care that is used to treat conditions such as airway obstruction, respiratory arrest, and cardiac arrest.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Elements of BLS			Subject:BLS Resuscitation, Page 557			Title: BLS Resuscitation			Feedback: See Elements of BLS			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 14-1 Explain the elements of basic life support (BLS), how it differs from advanced life support (ALS), and why BLS must be applied rapidly.
MC
After ________ minutes without oxygen, permanent brain damage is possible.

column3: a) 1 to 2
b) 4 to 6
c) 2 to 3

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Elements of BLS			Subject:BLS Resuscitation, Page 557			Title: BLS Resuscitation			Feedback: See Elements of BLS			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 14-1 Explain the elements of basic life support (BLS), how it differs from advanced life support (ALS), and why BLS must be applied rapidly.
MC
After establishing that an adult patient is unresponsive, you should:

column3: a) manually open the airway.
b) assess for breathing and a pulse.
c) immediately begin chest compressions.
d) apply the AED and deliver a shock, if needed.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Assessing the Need for BLS			Subject:BLS Resuscitation, Page 561			Title: BLS Resuscitation			Feedback: See Assessing the Need for BLS			Taxonomy: Application			Objective: 14-2 Explain the goals of cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) and when it should be performed on a patient.
MC
Which of the following is NOT a BLS intervention?

column3: a) Abdominal thrusts
b) Chest compressions
c) Cardiac monitoring
d) Automated defibrillation

MC: Complexity: Easy			Ahead: Elements of BLS			Subject:BLS Resuscitation, Page 558			Title: BLS Resuscitation			Feedback: See Elements of BLS			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 14-1 Explain the elements of basic life support (BLS), how it differs from advanced life support (ALS), and why BLS must be applied rapidly.
MC
Most prehospital cardiac arrests in adults occur as the result of:

column3: a) severe blunt trauma.
b) a cardiac dysrhythmia.
c) an acute ischemic stroke.
d) obstruction of the airway.

MC: Complexity: Easy			Ahead: Automated External Defibrillation			Subject:BLS Resuscitation, Page 561			Title: BLS Resuscitation			Feedback: See Automated External Defibrillation			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 14-4 Discuss guidelines for circumstances that require the use of an automated external defibrillator (AED) on both adult and pediatric patients experiencing cardiac arrest.
MC
Which of the following statements regarding ventricular fibrillation (VF) is correct?

column3: a) VF is a state of rapid ventricular contraction.
b) Most patients in VF have a weak carotid pulse.
c) Defibrillation is only indicated for witnessed VF.
d) VF results in an absence of forward blood flow.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Automated External Defibrillation			Subject:BLS Resuscitation, Page 561			Title: BLS Resuscitation			Feedback: See Automated External Defibrillation			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 14-4 Discuss guidelines for circumstances that require the use of an automated external defibrillator (AED) on both adult and pediatric patients experiencing cardiac arrest.
MC
You and your partner arrive at the side of a 60-year-old woman who collapsed about 7 minutes ago. She is unresponsive, apneic, and pulseless. You should:

column3: a) begin CPR and apply the AED as soon as it is available.
b) immediately apply the AED and analyze her cardiac rhythm.
c) begin CPR at a compression to ventilation ratio of 15:2.
d) apply the AED if there is no response after 10 cycles of CPR.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Automated External Defibrillation			Subject:BLS Resuscitation, Page 562			Title: BLS Resuscitation			Feedback: See Automated External Defibrillation			Taxonomy: Application			Objective: 14-2 Explain the goals of cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) and when it should be performed on a patient.
MC
Which of the following statements regarding the use of an AED in children is correct?

column3: a) If the patient is less than 1 year of age, an AED is preferred over a manual defibrillator.
b) AEDs are only effective in pediatric patients if severe trauma is the cause of their cardiac arrest.
c) AEDs can be used safely on infants and children by using pediatric pads and an energy reducer.
d) AEDs are not used in pediatric patients because they do not experience ventricular fibrillation.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Automated External Defibrillation			Subject:BLS Resuscitation, Page 562			Title: BLS Resuscitation			Feedback: See Automated External Defibrillation			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 14-4 Discuss guidelines for circumstances that require the use of an automated external defibrillator (AED) on both adult and pediatric patients experiencing cardiac arrest.
MC

Your partner is performing one-rescuer CPR on a middle-aged woman in cardiac arrest. When you apply the AED pads, you note that she has a medication patch over the same area where one of the AED pads will be placed. You should:

column3: a) apply the AED pad at least 1 inch away from the medication patch to avoid skin burns.
b) continue CPR until you can determine the name of the medication contained in the patch.
c) move the patch to another area of the patient’s chest and then properly apply the AED pad.
d) remove the medication patch, wipe away any medication residue, and apply the AED pad.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Automated External Defibrillation			Subject:BLS Resuscitation, Page 562			Title: BLS Resuscitation			Feedback: See Automated External Defibrillation			Taxonomy: Application			Objective: 14-5 Explain three special situations related to the use of an AED.
MC
Which of the following maneuvers should be used to open a patient’s airway when a spinal injury is suspected?

column3: a) Jaw-thrust
b) Tongue–jaw lift
c) Head tilt–neck lift
d) Head tilt–chin lift

MC: Complexity: Easy			Ahead: Opening the Airway and Providing Artificial Ventilation			Subject:BLS Resuscitation, Page 566			Title: BLS Resuscitation			Feedback: See Opening the Airway and Providing Artificial Ventilation			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 14-8 Describe the two techniques EMTs may use to open an adult patient’s airway and the circumstances that would determine when each technique would be used.
MC
Several attempts to adequately open a trauma patient’s airway with the jaw-thrust maneuver have been unsuccessful. You should:

column3: a) try opening the airway by lifting up on the chin.
b) carefully perform the head tilt–chin lift maneuver.
c) tilt the head back while lifting up on the patient’s neck.
d) suction the airway and reattempt the jaw-thrust maneuver.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Opening the Airway and Providing Artificial Ventilation			Subject:BLS Resuscitation, Page 566			Title: BLS Resuscitation			Feedback: See Opening the Airway and Providing Artificial Ventilation			Taxonomy: Application			Objective: 14-8 Describe the two techniques EMTs may use to open an adult patient’s airway and the circumstances that would determine when each technique would be used.
MC
A patient should be placed in the recovery position when he or she:

column3: a) is semiconscious, injured, and breathing adequately.
b) has experienced trauma but is breathing effectively.
c) is unresponsive, uninjured, and breathing adequately.
d) has a pulse but is unresponsive and breathing shallowly.

MC: Complexity: Easy			Ahead: Opening the Airway and Providing Artificial Ventilation			Subject:BLS Resuscitation, Page 567			Title: BLS Resuscitation			Feedback: See Opening the Airway and Providing Artificial Ventilation			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 14-9 Describe the recovery position and circumstances that would warrant its use as well as situations in which it would be contraindicated.
MC
When performing chest compressions on an adult, the EMT should compress:

column3: a) at least 1 inch
b) at least 2 inches
c) between 1 inch and 2 inches
d) greater than 2.4 inches

MC: Complexity: Easy			Ahead: Elements of BLS			Subject:BLS Resuscitation, Page 557			Title: BLS Resuscitation			Feedback: See Elements of BLS			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 14-7 Describe the purpose of external chest compressions.
MC
When ventilating an apneic adult with a bag-mask device, you should deliver each breath:

column3: a) over a period of about 2 to 3 seconds.
b) while watching for adequate chest rise.
c) every 2 to 3 seconds (20 to 30 breaths/min).
d) quickly to ensure adequate ventilation.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Opening the Airway and Providing Artificial Ventilation			Subject:BLS Resuscitation, Page 568			Title: BLS Resuscitation			Feedback: See Opening the Airway and Providing Artificial Ventilation			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 14-8 Describe the two techniques EMTs may use to open an adult patient’s airway and the circumstances that would determine when each technique would be used.
MC
Gastric distention will MOST likely occur:

column3: a) in patients who are intubated.
b) if you ventilate a patient too quickly.
c) when you deliver minimal tidal volume.
d) when the airway is completely obstructed.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Opening the Airway and Providing Artificial Ventilation			Subject:BLS Resuscitation, Page 568			Title: BLS Resuscitation			Feedback: See Opening the Airway and Providing Artificial Ventilation			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 14-10 Describe the process of providing artificial ventilations to an adult patient, ways to avoid gastric distention, and modifications required for a patient with a stoma.
MC
If gastric distention begins to make positive-pressure ventilation difficult, you should:

column3: a) reposition the patient’s airway
b) suction the patient’s oropharynx
c) insert an oropharyngeal airway.
d) increase the rate of ventilation.

MC: Complexity: Easy			Ahead: Opening the Airway and Providing Artificial Ventilation			Subject:BLS Resuscitation, Page 569			Title: BLS Resuscitation			Feedback: See Opening the Airway and Providing Artificial Ventilation			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 14-10 Describe the process of providing artificial ventilations to an adult patient, ways to avoid gastric distention, and modifications required for a patient with a stoma.
MC
CPR will NOT be effective if the patient is:

column3: a) prone.
b) supine.
c) horizontal.
d) on a firm surface.

MC: Complexity: Easy			Ahead: Positioning the Patient			Subject:BLS Resuscitation, Page 563			Title: BLS Resuscitation			Feedback: See Positioning the Patient			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 14-6 Describe the proper way to position an adult patient to receive BLS care.
MC
You should deliver chest compressions to an unresponsive adult patient in cardiac arrest by:

column3: a) compressing quickly and releasing slowly.
b) compressing the sternum between the nipples.
c) placing the heel of your hand on the xiphoid.
d) depressing the sternum more than 2.5 inches in depth.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Check for Breathing and a Pulse			Subject:BLS Resuscitation, Page 563			Title: BLS Resuscitation			Feedback: See Check for Breathing and a Pulse			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 14-7 Describe the purpose of external chest compressions.
MC
Complications associated with chest compressions include all of the following, EXCEPT:

column3: a) rib fractures.
b) liver laceration.
c) gastric distention.
d) a fractured sternum.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Check for Breathing and a Pulse			Subject:BLS Resuscitation, Page 565			Title: BLS Resuscitation			Feedback: See Check for Breathing and a Pulse			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 14-7 Describe the purpose of external chest compressions.
MC
A 60-year-old man is found to be unresponsive, pulseless, and apneic. You should:

column3: a) start CPR and transport immediately.
b) withhold CPR until he is defibrillated.
c) determine if he has a valid living will.
d) begin CPR until an AED is available.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: One-Rescuer Adult CPR			Subject:BLS Resuscitation, Page 571			Title: BLS Resuscitation			Feedback: See One-Rescuer Adult CPR			Taxonomy: Application			Objective: 14-11 Explain the steps in providing single-rescuer adult CPR.
MC
To ensure that you will deliver the appropriate number of chest compressions during one-rescuer adult CPR, you should compress the patient’s chest at a rate of:

column3: a) 80 to 100 compressions per minute.
b) at least 120 compressions per minute.
c) 100 to 120 compressions per minute.
d) no greater than 100 compressions per minute.

MC: Complexity: Easy			Ahead: One-Rescuer Adult CPR			Subject:BLS Resuscitation, Page 571			Title: BLS Resuscitation			Feedback: See One-Rescuer Adult CPR			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 14-11 Explain the steps in providing single-rescuer adult CPR.
MC
In two-rescuer adult CPR, you should deliver a compression to ventilation ratio of:

Complexity: Easy			Ahead: Two-Rescuer Adult CPR			Subject:BLS Resuscitation, Page 568			Title: BLS Resuscitation			Feedback: See Two-Rescuer Adult CPR			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 14-12 Explain the steps in providing two-rescuer adult CPR, including the method for switching positions during the process.
MC
After an advanced airway device has been inserted during two-rescuer CPR, you should:

column3: a) pause compressions to deliver ventilations.
b) deliver one rescue breath every 6 seconds.
c) decrease the compression rate to about 80 per minute.
d) increase rescue breathing to a rate of 14 breaths/min.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Two-Rescuer Adult CPR			Subject:BLS Resuscitation, Page 571			Title: BLS Resuscitation			Feedback: See Two-Rescuer Adult CPR			Taxonomy: Application			Objective: 14-12 Explain the steps in providing two-rescuer adult CPR, including the method for switching positions during the process.
MC
While rescuer one is finishing his or her fifth cycle of 30 compressions, rescuer two should:

column3: a) assess for a carotid pulse for 15 seconds.
b) move to the opposite side of the patient’s chest.
c) give two breaths and prepare to start compressions.
d) suction the patient’s mouth and give two more ventilations.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Two-Rescuer Adult CPR			Subject:BLS Resuscitation, Page 573			Title: BLS Resuscitation			Feedback: See Two-Rescuer Adult CPR			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 14-12 Explain the steps in providing two-rescuer adult CPR, including the method for switching positions during the process.
MC
The impedance threshold device (ITD) may improve circulation during active compression-decompression CPR by:

column3: a) maintaining increased intrathoracic pressure during the downward stroke of each chest compression, which forces more blood from both of the ventricles.
b) maximizing the amount of air in the lungs following chest recoil, which hyperinflates the lungs and forces more blood from the ventricle during each compression.
c) drawing all of the air out of the lungs in between chest compressions, which causes positive intrathoracic pressure and a reduction of blood return to the right side of the heart.
d) limiting the amount of air that enters the lungs during the recoil phase between chest compressions, which results in negative intrathoracic pressure and improved cardiac filling.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Devices and Techniques to Assist Circulation			Subject:BLS Resuscitation, Page 575			Title: BLS Resuscitation			Feedback: See Devices and Techniques to Assist Circulation			Taxonomy: Analysis			Objective: 14-13 Describe the different mechanical devices that are available to assist emergency care providers in delivering improved circulatory efforts during CPR.
MC
The main benefit of using a mechanical piston device for chest compressions is:

column3: a) the minimal training required to correctly operate the device.
b) the elimination of rescuer fatigue that results from manual compressions.
c) the elimination of the need to place a firm, flat device under the patient.
d) its ability to be used with any patient, regardless of age, weight, or body size.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Devices and Techniques to Assist Circulation			Subject:BLS Resuscitation, Page 576			Title: BLS Resuscitation			Feedback: See Devices and Techniques to Assist Circulation			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 14-13 Describe the different mechanical devices that are available to assist emergency care providers in delivering improved circulatory efforts during CPR.
MC
In most cases, cardiopulmonary arrest in infants and children is caused by:

column3: a) a drug overdose.
b) respiratory arrest.
c) severe chest trauma.
d) a cardiac dysrhythmia.

MC: Complexity: Easy			Ahead: Infant and Child CPR			Subject:BLS Resuscitation, Page 577			Title: BLS Resuscitation			Feedback: See Infant and Child CPR			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 14-14 Describe the different possible causes of cardiopulmonary arrest in children.
MC
The proper depth of chest compressions on a 9-month-old infant is:

column3: a) one third the diameter of the chest, or about 1½ inches.
b) one half to two thirds the diameter of the chest.
c) one half the diameter of the chest, or about 1½ inches.
d) two thirds the diameter of the chest, or about 2 inches.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Infant and Child CPR			Subject:BLS Resuscitation, Page 578			Title: BLS Resuscitation			Feedback: See Infant and Child CPR			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 14-15 Explain the four steps of pediatric BLS procedures and how they differ from BLS procedures used in an adult patient.
MC
What is the minimum number of chest compressions that should be delivered per minute to a 4-month-old infant?

Complexity: Easy			Ahead: Infant and Child CPR			Subject:BLS Resuscitation, Page 578			Title: BLS Resuscitation			Feedback: See Infant and Child CPR			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 14-15 Explain the four steps of pediatric BLS procedures and how they differ from BLS procedures used in an adult patient.
MC
When assessing the pulse of an unresponsive infant, you should palpate the ________ artery.

column3: a) radial
b) carotid
c) femoral
d) brachial

MC: Complexity: Easy			Ahead: Infant and Child CPR			Subject:BLS Resuscitation, Page 578			Title: BLS Resuscitation			Feedback: See Infant and Child CPR			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 14-15 Explain the four steps of pediatric BLS procedures and how they differ from BLS procedures used in an adult patient.
MC
What is the correct ratio of compressions to ventilations when performing two-rescuer child CPR?

Complexity: Easy			Ahead: Infant and Child CPR			Subject:BLS Resuscitation, Page 580			Title: BLS Resuscitation			Feedback: See Infant and Child CPR			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 14-15 Explain the four steps of pediatric BLS procedures and how they differ from BLS procedures used in an adult patient.
MC
When performing CPR on a child, you should compress the chest:

column3: a) until a radial pulse is felt.
b) with one or two hands.
c) to a depth of 1 to 2 inches.
d) 80 to 100 times per minute.

MC: Complexity: Easy			Ahead: Infant and Child CPR			Subject:BLS Resuscitation, Page 578			Title: BLS Resuscitation			Feedback: See Infant and Child CPR			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 14-15 Explain the four steps of pediatric BLS procedures and how they differ from BLS procedures used in an adult patient.
MC
Which of the following is considered an obvious sign of death and would not require the initiation of CPR?

column3: a) Dependent blood pooling
b) Pulselessness and apnea
c) Agonal respiratory effort
d) Severe cyanosis to the face

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: When Not to Start CPR			Subject:BLS Resuscitation, Page 584			Title: BLS Resuscitation			Feedback: See When Not to Start CPR			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 14-16 Describe the ethical issues related to patient resuscitation, including examples of when not to start CPR on a patient.
MC
CPR should be initiated when:

column3: a) rigor mortis is obvious.
b) a valid living will is unavailable.
c) the carotid pulse is very weak.
d) signs of putrefaction are present.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: When Not to Start CPR			Subject:BLS Resuscitation, Page 583			Title: BLS Resuscitation			Feedback: See When Not to Start CPR			Taxonomy: Analysis			Objective: 14-16 Describe the ethical issues related to patient resuscitation, including examples of when not to start CPR on a patient.
MC
Which of the following is NOT an indication to stop CPR once you have started?

column3: a) Pulse and respirations return.
b) You are physically exhausted.
c) A physician directs you to do so.
d) Care is transferred to a bystander.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: When to Stop CPR			Subject:BLS Resuscitation, Page 586			Title: BLS Resuscitation			Feedback: See When to Stop CPR			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 14-17 Explain the various factors involved in the decision to stop CPR after it has been started on a patient.
MC
The MOST appropriate treatment for a patient with a mild upper airway obstruction includes:

column3: a) performing five back slaps and five abdominal thrusts.
b) visualizing the airway and removing the obstruction.
c) administering oxygen and transporting immediately.
d) advising the patient not to make any attempts to cough.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Foreign Body Airway Obstruction in Adults			Subject:BLS Resuscitation, Page 587			Title: BLS Resuscitation			Feedback: See Foreign Body Airway Obstruction in Adults			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 14-18 Explain common causes of foreign body airway obstruction in both children and adults and how to distinguish mild or partial airway obstruction from complete airway obstruction.
MC
Signs of a sudden severe upper airway obstruction include all of the following, EXCEPT:

column3: a) acute cyanosis.
b) inability to speak.
c) grasping the throat.
d) forceful coughing.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Foreign Body Airway Obstruction in Adults			Subject:BLS Resuscitation, Page 587			Title: BLS Resuscitation			Feedback: See Foreign Body Airway Obstruction in Adults			Taxonomy: Analysis			Objective: 14-18 Explain common causes of foreign body airway obstruction in both children and adults and how to distinguish mild or partial airway obstruction from complete airway obstruction.
MC
Abdominal thrusts in a conscious child or adult with a severe upper airway obstruction are performed:

column3: a) until he or she loses consciousness.
b) in sets of five followed by reassessment.
c) about 1 inch below the xiphoid process.
d) until he or she experiences cardiac arrest.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Foreign Body Airway Obstruction in Adults			Subject:BLS Resuscitation, Page 588			Title: BLS Resuscitation			Feedback: See Foreign Body Airway Obstruction in Adults			Taxonomy: Application			Objective: 14-18 Explain common causes of foreign body airway obstruction in both children and adults and how to distinguish mild or partial airway obstruction from complete airway obstruction.
MC
Which of the following techniques should you use to dislodge a foreign body airway obstruction in a patient who is in an advanced stage of pregnancy or who is very obese?

column3: a) Back slaps
b) Finger sweeps
c) Chest thrusts
d) Abdominal thrusts

MC: Complexity: Easy			Ahead: Foreign Body Airway Obstruction in Adults			Subject:BLS Resuscitation, Page 588			Title: BLS Resuscitation			Feedback: See Foreign Body Airway Obstruction in Adults			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 14-19 Describe the different methods for removing a foreign body airway obstruction in an infant, child, and adult, including the procedure for a patient with an obstruction who becomes unresponsive.
MC
Your initial attempt to ventilate an unresponsive, apneic 30-year-old man is met with resistance and you do not see the chest rise. Your second ventilation attempt is also unsuccessful. You should:

column3: a) suction the oropharynx.
b) perform a blind finger sweep.
c) perform 30 chest compressions.
d) ventilate again with greater force.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Foreign Body Airway Obstruction in Adults			Subject:BLS Resuscitation, Page 589			Title: BLS Resuscitation			Feedback: See Foreign Body Airway Obstruction in Adults			Taxonomy: Application			Objective: 14-19 Describe the different methods for removing a foreign body airway obstruction in an infant, child, and adult, including the procedure for a patient with an obstruction who becomes unresponsive.
MC
Initial treatment to dislodge a severe foreign body airway obstruction in a responsive infant involves:

column3: a) back slaps.
b) bag-mask ventilation.
c) abdominal thrusts.
d) blind finger sweeps.

MC: Complexity: Easy			Ahead: Foreign Body Airway Obstruction in Infants and Children			Subject:BLS Resuscitation, Page 591			Title: BLS Resuscitation			Feedback: See Foreign Body Airway Obstruction in Infants and Children			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 14-19 Describe the different methods for removing a foreign body airway obstruction in an infant, child, and adult, including the procedure for a patient with an obstruction who becomes unresponsive.
MC
CPR is in progress on a pregnant woman. Shortly after manually displacing her uterus to the left, return of spontaneous circulation occurs. Which of the following would MOST likely explain this?

column3: a) Increased blood flow to her heart caused her ventricles to stop fibrillating, which restored her pulse.
b) Pressure was relieved from her aorta and vena cava, which improved chest compression effectiveness.
c) Displacement of her uterus caused blood to flow backward, which increased blood flow to her heart.
d) Displacement of her uterus allowed her lungs to expand more fully, which restored her pulse.

MC: Complexity: Difficult			Ahead: Special Resuscitation Circumstances			Subject:BLS Resuscitation, Page 593			Title: BLS Resuscitation			Feedback: See Special Resuscitation Circumstances			Taxonomy: Analysis			Objective: 14-16 Describe the ethical issues related to patient resuscitation, including examples of when not to start CPR on a patient.
MC
A team of EMTs and paramedics are attempting to resuscitate a man who is in cardiac arrest while his wife and son are present. Which of the following should occur during the resuscitation attempt?

column3: a) One EMT should update the family on the interventions that have been performed and how the patient has responded.
b) Each member of the resuscitation team should update the family at various intervals throughout the attempt.
c) Communication with the family should be minimal until the final outcome of the resuscitation attempt is known.
d) A law enforcement officer should prepare the family for the patient’s death and contact the funeral home.

MC: Complexity: Difficult			Ahead: Grief Support for Family Members and Loved Ones			Subject:BLS Resuscitation, Page 594			Title: BLS Resuscitation			Feedback: See Grief Support for Family Members and Loved Ones			Taxonomy: Application			Objective: 14-20 Discuss how to provide grief support for a patient’s family members and loved ones after resuscitation has ended.
MC
CPR retraining is the MOST effective when it:

column3: a) is self-paced and brief.
b) occurs every 24 months.
c) is delivered by computer.
d) involves hands-on practice.

MC: Complexity: Easy			Ahead: Education and Training for the EMT			Subject:BLS Resuscitation, Page 595			Title: BLS Resuscitation			Feedback: See Education and Training for the EMT			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 14-21 Discuss the importance of frequent CPR training for EMTs, as well as public education programs that teach compression-only CPR.
MC
You should attempt to maintain a chest compression fraction of at least:

Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Interrupting CPR			Subject:BLS Resuscitation, Page 584			Title: BLS Resuscitation			Feedback: See Interrupting CPR			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 14-2 Explain the goals of cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) and when it should be performed on a patient.
MC

You are off duty at a park when you witness an apparently healthy 12-year-old child suddenly collapse. There are no bystanders around, and your mobile phone is in your car. After confirming that the child is in cardiac arrest, you should:

column3: a) perform CPR for 2 minutes and then call 9-1-1.
b) call 9-1-1 and then return to begin CPR on the child.
c) deliver five rescue breaths before starting chest compressions.
d) perform chest compressions only until a bystander arrives.

MC: Complexity: Difficult			Ahead: Infant and Child CPR			Subject:BLS Resuscitation, Page 579			Title: BLS Resuscitation			Feedback: See Infant and Child CPR			Taxonomy: Application			Objective: 14-14 Describe the different possible causes of cardiopulmonary arrest in children.
